CHEVRON PHILLIPS CHEMICAL COMPANY LP
PASADENA PLASTICS COMPLEX
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN (RMP)
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

The Chevron Phillips Chemical Company LP, Pasadena Plastics Complex has a fundamental commitment to worker and public safety as demonstrated by a strict adherence to operational excellence principles and procedures.  Operating in a safe and environmentally protective manner are values held above all others.  Pasadena Plastics Complex is focused on preventing serious process-related incidents that might affect plant personnel, visitors, the community or the environment.  The process safety management (PSM) program demonstrates this focused commitment.  The PSM program involves the application of management systems and performance management practices to control process hazards through objectives, programs, procedures, audits, evaluations, and training that considers safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes.  

Continuous improvement in safety and environmental performance will be achieved, among other things, through the company's Employee Safety Process and its Tenets of Operation guiding principles.  Although the management systems for chemical process operations target continuous improvement in the storage, use, and manufacturing of regulated substances, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain a process-related incident in the event one should occur.  

Additionally, the management systems and performance management practices used at the Pasadena Plastics Complex are measured using Key Performance Indicators (KPIs).  Careful attention to the right measurements helps to ensure that performance trends, both positive and negative, are recognized early and are acted upon appropriately.

Safety and environmental incidents are to be reported immediately.  Subsequently, the incidents are to be investigated, the root causes are to be determined, and actions

are to be taken to avoid similar incidents in the future.  Investigations will be conducted with the objective of determining the causes and prevention of future incidents.

The knowledge that is gained from accident/incident reports, maintenance records, case histories, and trend analysis of incidents will provide basic information and potential changes that can be used to help further prevent catastrophic events.  As a tool to help manage this knowledge, Chevron Phillips Chemical Company has implemented a Knowledge Management System (KMS).  This corporate computer based system assists in tracking and sharing environmental, health and safety recommendations, changes and incidents.

DESCRIPTION OF STATIONARY SOURCES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Chevron Phillips Chemical Company LP Pasadena Plastics Complex located in Pasadena, Texas operates several plastic resin manufacturing processes and one specialty chemical manufacturing process. The plastic resin manufacturing processes utilize various regulated flammable chemicals such as ethylene, propylene, 1,3-butadiene, isobutane, propane, and pentane to produce plastic resin.   The plastic resin manufacturing process also utilizes the regulated toxic chemical chlorine in quantities below the threshold limit for process water treatment.
 The specialty chemical manufacturing process utilizes the regulated flammable chemicals such as ethylene, 2-methylpropene and propane to produce a specialty chemical.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The following is a summary of the general accident prevention programs in place at the Chevron Phillips Chemical Company LP, Pasadena Plastics Complex.  Pasadena Plastics Complex is an OSHA PSM regulated facility.  Therefore, the elements of the Pasadena Plastics Complex PSM program / OSHA PSM standard, which essentially mirror the prevention program requirement of the EPA's RMP standard, have been in place since 1992.

Employee Participation

The intent of employee particip

ation is to ensure that Pasadena Plastics Complex employees are informed, consulted and involved in all aspects of process safety management.  Employees have access to information developed to comply with the PSM standard in the Pasadena Plastics Complex Central Office Building Library.  Examples of employee participation range from reviewing process safety information and Standard Operating Procedures to serving on Process Hazard Analysis teams.  

Pasadena Plastics Complex also utilizes other processes such as company communication tools and the Employee Safety Process to keep employee participation evergreen and provide periodic reminders to the employees that their process safety concerns and suggestions are welcome. 

Process Safety Information (PSI)

Pasadena Plastics Complex compiles and maintains written process safety information to enable both the employer and employee the ability to effectively identify and understand the hazards posed by the process.  Written PSI provides employees with a baseline of information to identify hazards of the chemicals used or produced in the process, information about the technology of the process, and information about the equipment in the process.  This PSI provides the foundation for performing the unit Process Hazards Analysis, developing operating procedures, and determining the applicability of management of change. The record copy of this formation is maintained in the Pasadena Plastics Complex Central Office Building Library. 

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

A process hazard analysis is a detailed and systematic evaluation of all aspects of the process (equipment, chemicals, technology, and procedures) to identify the potential hazards associated with the processing and handling of highly hazardous chemicals.  PHAs are performed on existing and new units in all of Pasadena Plastics Complex's nine covered processes.  The Checklist and Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP), or other appropriate equivalent methodologies

, were used to perform the PHAs on each covered process at Pasadena Plastics Complex.  A PHA results in action items (findings/recommendations) that identify and address perceived potential hazards.  The action items are prioritized for management and employee resolution utilizing the scheme below:

Pasadena Plastics Complex additionally uses an Independent Protection Layer (IPL) Analysis methodology (commonly referred to as Layers of Protection Analysis or LOPA) to integrate process risk management into a unified, comprehensive program and identify Safety Instrumented Systems (SIS) in accordance with ANSI/ISA S84.01-1996 and IEC 61511.  

IPLs can be viewed as ?lines of defense? against a potential incident.  IPLs often decrease the frequency of the potential incident.  Independent Protection Layers (IPLs) are systems used to mitigate serious environmental and process safety risk, identified during the process hazard analysis.  IPLs include specific and identified standard operating procedures, alarms with operator response, safety instrumented systems, emergency shutdown systems, and protective devices.

IPL Analysis provides the risk assessment methodology for the Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) is an integral part of the PSM program. Action items are managed and tracked to completion.

Operating Procedures

Written standard operating procedures (SOP) provide clear instructions for the safe operations and control of the process and associated equipment.  SOP's are readily accessible to operations personnel in the control rooms and all other employees via the electronic delivery system.  The SOP's address various phases of operation, such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency operations; emergency shutdown, normal shutdown, and subsequent startup.  SOPs also address safety and health considerations and information on Safe Work Practices.  Revisions to SOP's may be prompted as a result of management of change, process hazard analysis

, an annual review of SOP's or input from employees using the SOP?s.

Training

Pasadena Plastics Complex has implemented a comprehensive training program for Pasadena Plastics Complex employees especially those involved in operating a process.  Operator Training has been developed to equip operators with the knowledge and skill necessary to safely and proficiently perform their job duties.  This training emphasized specific safety and health hazards, emergency operations including shutdown, and safe work practices applicable to the employee's job tasks.  Written tests, oral tests, observation, demonstration and peer evaluations are utilized to verify the training.

Refresher training/certification is provided every three years to operations personnel on the operating units for which they are responsible.  Training in safe work practices is given to employees during new employee safety orientation, annual safety training, special classes and monthly safety meetings.  

Contractors

Contract employees at Pasadena Plastics Complex provide labor for general maintenance or repairs, turnarounds, major renovations, construction, demolition, equipment installation or specialty work on or adjacent to covered processes.  Thus, their actions may have an influence on process safety.  Pasadena Plastics Complex informs contractors of known potentials fire, explosion or toxic release hazards related to the contractor's work and the process as well as the emergency action plan, safe work practices and sign-in/sign-out requirements for Pasadena Plastics Complex during the Contractor Safety Orientation.  The contractor employer is responsible for assuring that each contract employee is trained in the work practices necessary to safely perform his/her job.  

Mechanical Integrity

The intent of the mechanical integrity program is to provide a management system that ensures:  (1) the equipment is maintained in a manner to prevent or minimize the consequences of a catastrophic release

of a highly hazardous chemical and  (2) the equipment is maintained by trained and qualified personnel to assure its continued integrity.  The Mechanical Integrity Covered Equipment (MICE) at Pasadena Plastics Complex includes the following type of equipment: pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping, valves, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps.  The basic aspects of the mechanical integrity system include:  (1) design and construction requirements; (2) preventive maintenance practices; (3) testing and inspection; (4) repair, modification and alteration procedures; and (5) inspector and craftsman training and qualifications.  

Safe Work Practices

Pasadena Plastics Complex has many safe work practices that promote worker and process safety.  Examples of these include (1) hot work permits to control work involving flame or spark-producing operations; (2) confined space entry permits to ensure adequate safety precautions have been taken prior to entering vessels, tanks and other confined spaces; (3) lockout/tagout procedures to guarantee isolation of energy sources prior to working on equipment; and (4) pressure-relief device (PRD) removal procedures to ensure adequate alternate relief paths are available prior to removal of any PRD and (5) interlock and alarm bypassing procedures to ensure that critical process controls are managed properly.  These procedures, along with others, form a system to help make certain that operations and maintenance activities are performed in a safe manner.

Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Review

Pasadena Plastics Complex has a comprehensive system to manage changes to processes.  Changes may introduce new hazards or compromise safeguards incorporated in the original design of the process and must be reviewed prior to their implementation.   This system requires that change to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process-operating conditions), software, procedu

res (including operating, maintenance, and safe work) and emergency procedures be properly reviewed for potential hazards and authorized using the MOC/PSR Certification form and an electronic approval process before being implemented.  This system requires that any change executed address the following: the technical basis for the proposed change; the impact of the change on safety and health; modifications to operating procedures; necessary time period for change; and authorization requirements for the proposed change.  

Affected process safety information (e.g., mechanical, electrical/instrument, chemical, and operating limits) and procedures (e.g., operating, maintenance, and safe work) are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on the change.

Pasadena Plastics Complex conducts a Pre-startup Safety Review for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. A PSR is conducted for the following types of changes: equipment, facilities, and/or process chemicals, technology, and software. The PSR serves as a final check prior to the introduction of highly hazardous chemicals into the process at a new facility and conducted prior to start-up, commissioning, or engagement of the change, for existing, modified facilities.  The PSR must confirm the following: a PHA has been performed for new facilities and that PHA recommendations have been resolved; MOC requirements have been executed for changes to modified facilities; construction and equipment installation is in accordance with design specifications; training of each employee involved in operating a process has been completed; and, safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate. 

Incident Investigation

Incidents, which resulted in or reasonably could have resulted in a catastrophic release of a highly hazardous chemical, are investigated by

a cross-section of plant personnel. The composition of investigation teams varies with the complexity of the incident, but the underlying philosophy is one of employee/contractor employee involvement, as appropriate.  

Pasadena Plastics Complex is a member of the TOP (Triangle of Prevention) Program.  This program is a Systems of Safety process developed by PACE International Union utilizing a logic tree investigative methodology to determine the root causes of accidents, incidents and near misses.  The TOP program is comprised of three interdependent elements:  1) measurement of the success of the facility?s health and safety systems, 2) systems of safety and incident investigation training program and 3) a full-time union health and safety representative program.  The incident investigation process is fully administered by the TOP Facilitators.

Once the results of the incident investigation are available, incidents including findings and recommended actions are summarized and communicated throughout the Complex.  The full incident investigation report is available to any employee upon request through the Safety Department or through KMS.

An incident review team, comprised of a cross section of employees, meets on a monthly basis to review incidents that have occurred.  The review identifies important trends, global lessons learned and potential safety issues that need additional attention. The results of these reviews are shared with employees through the Sequential Safety Meeting process as part of the Employee Safety Process.

Compliance Audits

Pasadena Plastics Complex conducts compliance audits to periodically evaluate the effectiveness of the PSM Program at Pasadena Plastics Complex; to ensure that each program element complies with the standard; and to ascertain whether the programs' internal procedures and practices are adequate and are being implemented.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years.  The audit team is comprised of a vari

ety of multi-disciplined employees who utilize a set of self-audit checklists based on the OSHA PSM standard.  Audit findings and responses are entered and maintained in a corporate computer-based tracking system.  The final resolution of each finding is documented and the two most recent audit reports are retained.  

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION

The processes at Pasadena Plastics Complex have hazards that must be managed to help ensure continued safe operation.  The Accident Prevention Program summarized previously is applied to all OSHA PSM / EPA RMP covered processes at the plant.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by (1) equipment failures and (2) human errors.

In addition to the Accident Prevention Program activities, Pasadena Plastics Complex has safety features on many of its units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release.  The following types of safety features are used in various processes:

Release Detection.

Release detection system connected to a plant-wide Emergency Alarm System.

Release Containment/Control.

Periodic inspection of process equipment.

Inspections by Operators each shift.

Routine leak detection and repair program for all system components.

Remotely activated valves to isolate and limit release.

Emergency equipment shutdown systems that are activated automatically, locally or remotely.

Diked and sloped area with sump for spill containment.

Relief devices to prevent system overpressure.

Automatic overfill prevention instrumentation.

Specialized "excess flow" valves to restrict release.

State-of-the-art release prevention devices for pumps.

Process Relief Valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate releases.

Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated).

Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for

process control system, backup firewater pump).

Equipment designed and constructed to comply with industry codes, standards, and practices.

Internal and external audits to verify conformance with regulatory and Company standards.

Release Mitigation.

Established Emergency Response Plan.

State-of-the-art Emergency Alarm System.

Automatic water sprinkler system and fire hydrants with nozzles in specific areas.

Fire Suppression and Extinguishing Systems.

Mobile emergency response equipment.

Personal Protective Equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus).

Trained Emergency Responders onsite 24 hours/day.

Communications link to offsite response teams (CIMA and LEPC).

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

In the past five years, Pasadena Plastics Complex has experienced three accidents involving releases of regulated flammable substances that have resulted in deaths, injuries, significant property damage onsite, or offsite sheltering in place.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Pasadena Plastics Complex operates an extensive emergency response program to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  Pasadena Plastics Complex has several written documents, which detail the actions to be taken in response to an unwanted release of a highly hazardous chemical.  General Plant Safety Rules provide basic instructions to employees for reporting and responding to an emergency.  The Pasadena Plastics Complex Emergency Procedures Manual and the Emergency Action Plan further provide detailed instructions and information utilized by essential personnel with regard to the emergency planning and response systems that are implemented at Pasadena Plastics Complex. 

The Emergency Planning and Response Plan is developed and updated by a cross-section of plant personnel under the direction of the Safety Department.  A significant part of the Emergency Planning and Response Plan is the Pasadena Plastics Complex Emergency Response Team.  This team pr

ovides a significant part of all emergency response services for the facility.  This team is entirely comprised of employees who voluntarily participate as members of the team.  Membership requires participation in a rigorous training and qualification program.  Once qualified, each team member is expected to respond to emergency alarms while at work or if called out after their normal work shift.

The program consists of procedures for responding to various emergencies, including a small incidental emergency, a zone or complex-wide emergency, an external emergency, a hurricane or severe weather emergency, and a bomb threat.  The Incident Command System (ICS) is utilized to manage all emergency response situations.  The Pasadena Plastics Complex Emergency Response Team, a volunteer group of trained employees, responds to all plant emergencies to help minimize loss of like, property and to provide emergency medical care to the injured.  Trained Emergency Responders are onsite 24 hours per day.  

Pasadena Plastics Complex is divided into seven zones; all other areas are considered Outside Zones.  The zones are further divided into Affected Zones and Un-affected Zones depending upon the location and nature of the incident.  The Emergency Alarm System is designed to make either an Alarm or Announcement Tone followed by a voice message in the event of an incident.  The Emergency Alarm System is maintained to help response personnel or personnel working in either the Affected, Un-affected or Outside Zone determine the appropriate actions specified in the Emergency Action Plan.  Other communication tools include two-way radios and pagers.  

Pasadena Plastics Complex is a member of Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA), which is an organization of companies, and agencies that are prepared to handle their own normal emergencies, but are also prepared to lend emergency assistance to other members when it is requested.  Pasadena Plastics Complex is also involved with CAER (Co
mmunity Awareness and Emergency Response) and the Pasadena LEPC (Local Emergency Planning Committee).
